articles.headline: The Debt-Limit Deal Suggests Debt Will Keep Growing, Fast
articles.snippet: Negotiations to prevent a government default reaffirmed that the big drivers of future deficits are all off the table in a divided Washington.
articles.abstract: Negotiations to prevent a government default reaffirmed that the big drivers of future deficits are all off the table in a divided Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: The bipartisan deal to avert a government default this week featured modest cuts to a relatively small corner of the federal budget. As a curb on the growth of the nation’s $31.4 trillion debt load, it was a minor breakthrough, at best.

articles.headline: Welcome to CringeTok, Where Being Insufferable Can Be Lucrative
articles.snippet: On TikTok, cringe comedy creators are gaining large followings and brand deals by impersonating terrible people.
articles.abstract: On TikTok, cringe comedy creators are gaining large followings and brand deals by impersonating terrible people.
articles.lead_paragraph: During a three-part special examining the crimes of the serial killer Jeffrey Dahmer that aired last November on “Dr. Phil,” Phil McGraw, the host of the daytime talk show, played a TikTok video of a 27-year-old woman named Stanzi Potenza as evidence that true-crime fandom had gone too far. In the video, Ms. Potenza said she was so obsessed with Netflix’s “Monster: The Jeffrey Dahmer Story” that she stayed home from work in diapers to binge the series uninterrupted.

articles.headline: Vigilante Justice Rises in Haiti and Crime Plummets
articles.snippet: Civilians have killed at least 160 gang members in Haiti, a human rights group says. Residents say they feel safer, but others worry that it will lead to even more violence.
articles.abstract: Civilians have killed at least 160 gang members in Haiti, a human rights group says. Residents say they feel safer, but others worry that it will lead to even more violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: The 14 presumed gang members under arrest were arriving at a police station in Haiti’s capital, when a group of people overpowered the police, rounded up the suspects outside and used gasoline to burn them alive.
articles.byline: By Frances Robles and Andre Paultre

articles.headline: With Rainbow Flags, 2 Students Test China’s Shrinking L.G.B.T.Q. Space
articles.snippet: The students at an elite college in China found themselves on a collision course with the authorities amid a crackdown on gay and transgender expression.
articles.abstract: The students at an elite college in China found themselves on a collision course with the authorities amid a crackdown on gay and transgender expression.
articles.lead_paragraph: Karolyn Li still remembers reading the brochure from China’s prestigious Tsinghua University when she was in high school preparing to apply to college. It highlighted a graduate who had co-founded an L.G.B.T.Q. rights group, a suggestion of inclusivity on campus that surprised Ms. Li, who identifies as queer.
articles.byline: By Nicole Hong and Zixu Wang

articles.headline: In Russian Schools, It’s Recite Your ABC’s and ‘Love Your Army’
articles.snippet: The curriculum for young Russians is increasingly emphasizing patriotism and the heroism of Moscow’s army, while demonizing the West as “gangsters.” One school features a “sniper”-themed math class.
articles.abstract: The curriculum for young Russians is increasingly emphasizing patriotism and the heroism of Moscow’s army, while demonizing the West as “gangsters.” One school features a “sniper”-themed math class.
articles.lead_paragraph: A new version of the ABC’s in Russia’s Far East starts with “A is for Army, B is for Brotherhood” — and injects a snappy phrase with every letter, like, “Love your Army.”
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva

articles.headline: Two Black Members of Native Tribes Were Arrested. The Law Sees Only One as Indian.
articles.snippet: A Supreme Court ruling barred Oklahoma from prosecuting crimes committed by Native Americans on tribal land, but some Black tribal members are still being prosecuted because they lack “Indian blood.”
articles.abstract: A Supreme Court ruling barred Oklahoma from prosecuting crimes committed by Native Americans on tribal land, but some Black tribal members are still being prosecuted because they lack “Indian blood.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Early one morning in September 2020, Michael J. Hill called the police after hearing banging on the doors and windows of his home in Okmulgee, Okla. — part of a swath of the state that the Supreme Court had recently ruled to be tribal land.
articles.byline: By Chris Cameron and Mark Walker

articles.headline: India’s Worst Rail Disaster in Decades Convulses Country Dependent on Trains
articles.snippet: The disaster killed at least 288 people, and a preliminary government report described it as a “three-way accident” involving two passenger trains and an idled cargo train. Officials were investigating possible signal failure.
articles.abstract: The disaster killed at least 288 people, and a preliminary government report described it as a “three-way accident” involving two passenger trains and an idled cargo train. Officials were investigating possible signal failure.
articles.lead_paragraph: As giant excavators tried to untangle crushed trains on Saturday at the scene of India’s worst rail disaster in decades, a solemn scene was playing out at a small school a few hundred yards away.
articles.byline: By Sameer Yasir, Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar

articles.headline: ‘Everything Changed’: The War Arrives on Russians’ Doorstep
articles.snippet: With cross-border strikes, residents of the Russian region of Belgorod are starting to understand the horrors of war being waged at their doorstep.
articles.abstract: With cross-border strikes, residents of the Russian region of Belgorod are starting to understand the horrors of war being waged at their doorstep.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the last five days of May, Ruslan, an English teacher in a Russian town near the Ukrainian border, heard the distinct sound of a multiple rocket launcher strike for the first time. Shelling would begin around 3 a.m., sometimes shaking his house, and continue through the morning.
articles.byline: By Valerie Hopkins and Anatoly Kurmanaev

articles.headline: Inside the Complicated Reality of Being America’s Oldest President
articles.snippet: President Biden is asking voters to keep him in the White House until age 86, renewing attention to an issue that polls show troubles most Americans.
articles.abstract: President Biden is asking voters to keep him in the White House until age 86, renewing attention to an issue that polls show troubles most Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was the time last winter when President Biden was awakened at 3 a.m. while on a trip to Asia and told that a missile had struck Poland, touching off a panic that Russia might have expanded the war in Ukraine to a NATO ally. Within hours in the middle of the night, Mr. Biden consulted his top advisers, called the president of Poland and the NATO secretary general, and gathered fellow world leaders to deal with the crisis.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Michael D. Shear, Katie Rogers and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

articles.headline: In a Contentious Lawmaking Season, Red States Got Redder and Blue Ones Bluer
articles.snippet: With single-party statehouse control at its highest level in decades, legislators across much of the country leaned into cultural issues and bulldozed the opposition.
articles.abstract: With single-party statehouse control at its highest level in decades, legislators across much of the country leaned into cultural issues and bulldozed the opposition.
articles.lead_paragraph: America’s state capitals are as polarized as they have been in decades, with lawmakers imposing unflinchingly conservative or liberal agendas this year, even in politically diverse places.

articles.headline: Caribou Meat and Moon Signs: Inuit Lessons for Soldiers in the Arctic
articles.snippet: Humbled by centuries of fatal colonial expeditions, Canada’s military is learning Arctic survival strategies from the austere area’s only inhabitants.
articles.abstract: Humbled by centuries of fatal colonial expeditions, Canada’s military is learning Arctic survival strategies from the austere area’s only inhabitants.
articles.lead_paragraph: A moon dog hung low over the horizon. It showed up on the first day of the Canadian soldiers’ patrol, and the Inuit rangers guiding them in the country’s far north spotted it right away: Ice crystals in the clouds were bending the light, making two illusory moons appear in the sky.
articles.byline: By Norimitsu Onishi and Nasuna Stuart-Ulin

articles.headline: No Shame. No Sorrow. Divorce Means It’s Party Time in Mauritania.
articles.snippet: It is common for people in this West African desert nation to divorce many times. And when they do, the women celebrate.
articles.abstract: It is common for people in this West African desert nation to divorce many times. And when they do, the women celebrate.
articles.lead_paragraph: The henna artist bent over her client’s hand, glancing at the smartphone to get the precise details of the pattern chosen by her customer, a young woman living in an ancient desert city in the West African nation of Mauritania.
articles.byline: By Ruth Maclean and Laura Boushnak

articles.headline: In a Year of Capitol Feuds, Oregon Has a Political Breakdown
articles.snippet: Bipartisan collaboration was once a point of pride in Oregon, where Republicans have brought the Senate to a halt with a political boycott.
articles.abstract: Bipartisan collaboration was once a point of pride in Oregon, where Republicans have brought the Senate to a halt with a political boycott.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the past month, the Oregon Senate has started its daily proceedings by dispatching a search party.

articles.headline: These Activists Distrust Voting Machines. Just Don’t Call Them Election Deniers.
articles.snippet: As election activists rally against new voting machines, they are drifting into territory now dominated by conspiracy theorists.
articles.abstract: As election activists rally against new voting machines, they are drifting into territory now dominated by conspiracy theorists.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, Lulu Friesdat made election integrity her life’s work. Drawing support from activists and academics, she co-founded Smart Elections, a nonpartisan group that is opposed to some voting machines that Ms. Friesdat believes would increase wait times and cost a small fortune to purchase and maintain.

articles.headline: Could Jeff Zucker Fix CNN? He Seems to Think So.
articles.snippet: It’s been more than a year since he was forced from the top job at the network. Since then, he has made no secret of his frustrations with his exit — or his low regard for the man who replaced him, Chris Licht.
articles.abstract: It’s been more than a year since he was forced from the top job at the network. Since then, he has made no secret of his frustrations with his exit — or his low regard for the man who replaced him, Chris Licht.
articles.lead_paragraph: The seminar was to be on media leadership. Dozens of students filling a classroom at Yale University in April were there to learn about the business from a man who had commanded attention in TV control rooms and corporate boardrooms for decades before a stunning exit last year.

articles.headline: Chuck Todd to Leave ‘Meet the Press’
articles.snippet: He will be succeeded by Kristen Welker, NBC’s chief White House correspondent and the co-anchor of “Weekend Today.”
articles.abstract: He will be succeeded by Kristen Welker, NBC’s chief White House correspondent and the co-anchor of “Weekend Today.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Chuck Todd said on Sunday that he was stepping down from NBC’s “Meet the Press” after nine years in the moderator’s chair and would be succeeded by the network’s chief White House correspondent, Kristen Welker.

articles.headline: The Man Reimagining Disney Classics for Today’s World
articles.snippet: Sean Bailey is in charge of live-action remakes of films like “The Little Mermaid.” It’s a job that puts him in the middle of a partisan divide.
articles.abstract: Sean Bailey is in charge of live-action remakes of films like “The Little Mermaid.” It’s a job that puts him in the middle of a partisan divide.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, Sean Bailey has run Disney’s animated film “reimagining” factory with quiet efficiency and superhero-sized results. His live-action “Aladdin” collected $1.1 billion at the box office, while a photorealistic “The Lion King” took in $1.7 billion. A live-action “Beauty and the Beast” delivered $1.3 billion.

articles.headline: Saudi Arabia Says It Will Cut Production to Stem a Slide in Oil Prices
articles.snippet: OPEC Plus, the group of major oil producers, said it would continue its recent cuts in output, but Saudi Arabia said it would cut further for at least a month.
articles.abstract: OPEC Plus, the group of major oil producers, said it would continue its recent cuts in output, but Saudi Arabia said it would cut further for at least a month.
articles.lead_paragraph: The group of major oil-producing countries known as OPEC Plus agreed on Sunday to embark on a complex effort to adjust production as it aimed to halt the recent slide in oil prices, including an additional cut in output of one million barrels a day by Saudi Arabia.

articles.headline: Money for Show Horses, Not Work Horses, on India’s Rails
articles.snippet: Train travel in the country has gotten much safer, Friday’s disaster notwithstanding, but the government still puts high-profile projects ahead of basic safety improvements, analysts say.
articles.abstract: Train travel in the country has gotten much safer, Friday’s disaster notwithstanding, but the government still puts high-profile projects ahead of basic safety improvements, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a country where major industry and political fortunes alike are often tied to a vast, interwoven rail system, India has lavished public resources on new trains, but its purse strings have been much tighter when it comes to ensuring the safety of those already racing along its tracks.

articles.headline: Schools Received Billions in Stimulus Funds. It May Not Be Doing Enough.
articles.snippet: Pandemic aid was supposed to help students recover from learning loss, but results have been mixed.
articles.abstract: Pandemic aid was supposed to help students recover from learning loss, but results have been mixed.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the pandemic shut down schools across the country, the federal government responded with billions of dollars to help districts support remote learning, serve free meals to students and safely reopen schools.

articles.headline: Twitter’s U.S. Ad Sales Plunge 59% as Woes Continue
articles.snippet: In internal forecasts, the company projected that ad sales would keep declining, handing a tough challenge to its new chief executive.
articles.abstract: In internal forecasts, the company projected that ad sales would keep declining, handing a tough challenge to its new chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elon Musk recently said Twitter’s advertising business was on the upswing. “Almost all advertisers have come back,” he asserted, adding that the social media company could soon become profitable.
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: He Devoted His Life to Compassion. His Killer Showed None.
articles.snippet: After graduating from Stanford, David Breaux struggled to find his path — until he found his calling as “the Compassion Guy.”
articles.abstract: After graduating from Stanford, David Breaux struggled to find his path — until he found his calling as “the Compassion Guy.”
articles.lead_paragraph: It felt as if he had always been there, a steady sight on a busy corner in a college town.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Accuses Binance of Mishandling Funds and Lying to Regulators
articles.snippet: The S.E.C. said the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchange mixed billions of dollars in customer funds and secretly sent them to a separate company controlled by Binance’s founder, Changpeng Zhao.
articles.abstract: The S.E.C. said the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchange mixed billions of dollars in customer funds and secretly sent them to a separate company controlled by Binance’s founder, Changpeng Zhao.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday accused Binance, the world’s largest cryptocurrency exchange, of mishandling customer funds and lying to American regulators and investors about its operations, in a sweeping case that has the potential to remake the landscape of power and wealth within crypto.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein, Emily Flitter and David Yaffe-Bellany
